name: Tengami
description: Tengami is an atmospheric adventure game set inside a Japanese pop-up book. Fold and slide the beautifully crafted paper world to solve puzzles and discover secrets.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista Processor: Core 2 Duo Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Open GL 2.1 compatible graphics card Storage: 900 MB available space

reviews.review_text: This is a nice game, very pretty with new game mechanics. A breath of fresh air in video gaming.  But there are no save slots. I have no idea how long the game is, but I played for an hour and left. My only choice now is to start a new game and I need to have an hour to cover that ground again, plus whatever to finish the game.  Sorry, I'm really not looking to solve all those puzzles again in addition to having to sit down for a stretch of who knows how long that is at least an hour. This is not a good game mechanic and it is this reason why I do not reccomend it.

Very original game mechanisms, nice soundtrack, nice graphics and relaxing game  Why not recommending it then?  Because the game doesn't exploit the mechanisms it has put in place. It's very linear and after the first ten minutes, it's pretty much all the same  Because the puzzles are too repetitive and, again, don't exploit the original idea of folding and unfolding the crafted paper world  Because the soundtrack often ends abruptly for no reasons  Because there's no walk fast/running option. Seriously, the character moves sloooowly. I know it's supposed to be part of the general relaxing experience but it ended up annoying me and not relaxing me  Because the game is very short - finished it in one sitting of 90 minutes, getting all the achievements - and has no replay value  Because for those reasons, $10 for this game is way too much expensive. This game should cost $2 at full price  Overall, very clever idea, bad execution

Very atmospheric and beautiful game, albeit a little short. Though, I do believe it suits the game well.  I recommend this game to anybody who is interested in an adventure/puzzle game that is not tediously long; or to somebody who is looking for a nice change of pace.

There's no doubting this is a beautiful 1-2 hour casual/exploration/puzzle game, and the popup book simulation is clever. There's some nice atmosphere in terms of the varied palette and the art, music and sound effects in general.  But I feel the game failed to live up to its potential. There's no real 'wow' moments, like I got from games done in a similar spirit, such as Kentucky Route Zero or Monument Valley. Here are two major failings:    Puzzles. The puzzles aren't very engaging. I only enjoyed one where you flip through 3 columns of terrain to mix and match platforms, thereby forging a path to progress. The other puzzles are tedious at best. One puzzle requires you to count hidden symbols around the environment to crack a code. This is all done passively without any hint that it's even what you need to do. I used a walkthrough; no regrets.   Story. The game has only a basic shell of a story which isn't even marginally compelling. It is in fact based on a single haiku; a fairly clich√© one at that. It's the kind of one-dimensional first introduction you get of Japanese culture in a western primary school. As a western developed game, I feel they took a traditional Japanese aesthethic but failed to grasp the spirit of Japanese culture or storytelling.   In short, I didn't feel Tengami had any real passion put into its development. Since it's lacking both compelling gameplay and story, I'm left wondering who I'd recommend it to. I think it would only be suitable for a parent and child to play together, or as a source of inspiration for game developers.
Its a different type of puzzle game. Interesting nevertheless. 10 dollars worth? i think not. I got it while it was on sale, half off. sounds more like it.

I struggle to decide whether my feelings are more positive or negative towards this game.  The Pros: Very nice graphics, giving everything a 2D feel. Nice music, with an Asian feel to them, this matches up well with the graphics Some of the puzzles are nice, but others may fall under the category of 'you'll either get it right away or you'll be stuck for a while'  The Cons: I hesitate to mention pricing, but for the price of the game, it's incredibly short I'm not sure I really followed what the story the game is trying to tell is. If you're wandering about trying to solve a puzzle, it can take a long time as there's no 'sprinting'  If you like artsy pieces, you should try this game, otherwise it's not an amazing point-and-clicker.

I can't recommend this game at the asking price. It's too short. The game has an interest pop-up book aesthetic that factors into all of the game's puzzles. The puzzles themselves are interesting and can give you a good challenge, but the game is over entirely too quickly. If you can get it for a few bucks during a Steam sale, then by all means. Otherwise, just hold out.

A beautiful and original game set withing the realms of a pop up book. The audio work is outstandingly good. Puzzles gently lure you in then increase in difficulty towards the endgame. All in all a short but wonderful experience that I highly recommend.  9/10
This is an amazing game. Beautiful and thought-provoking. I really liked.

I enjoyed my time in this japanese style pop-up book. The art style and asthetic are the most impressive things about this game. It's short but sweet, and is quite relaxing as well. My only gripe is that the movement speed could be a bit faster. It's nothing revolutionary but if you're looking for a casual puzzle game then I can safely recommend this game.

A short and charming puzzle game. Don't expect any real brainbenders in this; this is an artistic game that's more about its atmosphere and experience than about its challenge. Designed in the style of a Japanese watercolor pop-up book, you'll manage to complete it in about an hour if you rush through it. But this is a game that you'll want to play to relax. Slow down, enjoy the music, take your time. That said, is it worth the $10 price tag? Nah. But if you can find it half off or more, it's definitely worth your time if you enjoy relaxing interactive artwork
The art is stunning! the game is great , truly a gem! 10/10 Highly recommend!
Absolutely stunning visuals. I wish it would be a bit longer, though.

A beautiful and memorable experience. Yet, unfortunately a rather short one that leaves you wishing for more. Tengami is a point-and-click adventure game that combines the beauty of vintage Asian art and pop-up books. Which uses almost no words what-so-ever. Leaving the player with the task of using their own imagination to piece it's story together. Overall, this game is very polished and shows that the small indie development team really put their heart and soul into making it. I in good faith, truly recommend this one to everyone.
Very nice game, simple but kind of charming. And the way they wrote hints, I like it. But could be much longer. You need only about an hour to finish it.

Short with under 2Hrs of game time, would have liked a little more . Simple yet engaging , puzzles make good use of the flip book mechanic.  Had some issues with audio , music would just stop when exploring and had some odd sounds cutting in at begining of game.

Be warned. This game doesn't even start for me. I get as far as the menu screen then nothing works. From what I've seen in the discussion pages, it seems to be an on-going issue with a numer of customers that's being looked into. Hopefully I'll get to play it some day and maybe even change my review to a 'Yes' but for now it's just been a total waste of money. Ironically, I had to keep the game open for a couple more minutes to even be able to leave this review/warning as Steam wouldn't even let me post it with 3 minutes of trying to get the game working with a message 'You need to have used this product for at least 5 minutes before posting a review for it (3 minutes on record).' Kind of hard to play a game for at least 5 minutes when it won't even start. :/

A classic point-and-click side-scroller that's sure to bore you into jaw-breaking yawns. Aside from that; pretty art, fair puzzles, and a short and easy journey into 100% achievement completion.  Tengami boring. But its pretty. And easy. Grandma on morphine.
Just finished this beautiful game. Very recommended

While the game itself is very beautiful, it lacks gameplay. The puzzles are too simple to be fun. The music is wonderful, but would abruptly turn off if you walked outside of the section. It took roughly an hour and a half to beat the entire game. The 4 achievements for the game are for beating it, killing any potential secret finding or replayability.  While a casual gamer or someone interested in art would probably find this a nice experience, I can't recommend it. Good game, but a small audience would enjoy it.   Other Reviews: I'm not sure what people are talking about with the save games. I had quit right after completing chapter 2, and pressed continue when I got back. And then finished chapter 3. Perhaps you can't save progress during the middle of a chapter?

I love when developers go outside the box when it comes to game machanics. The art flows smoothly with the pop-up book puzzles. A very relaxing game and the puzles are easy. My only complaint is that as soon as I start to enjoy the sound track it stops abruptly. Would have prefered a smoother cut off.

If you would like to get an elaborate concept art, Tengami is for you. It‚Äôs a wonderful, artistic pop-up book style adventure with great atmosphere and originality. If you would like to have an actual game however you will be disappointed because it‚Äôs nothing more than a prototype, an artistic experiment. It‚Äôs very short (I am not a fast player and I finished it in 30 minutes) and it doesn‚Äôt really have a story. I won‚Äôt recommend it in my review because I expected a game and though I really liked it, I would like to warn everyone who buys it after me.
very pretty game zen like it came from the east as life, far too short
Very fun, Very relaxing. There were some parts that really had me stumped but when I figured it out, it made the game that much more enjoyable.

After reading the reviews I was keen to try this game and was not disappointed. While the puzzles are not difficult, nor is the game play, I enjoyed the experience. The music, beautiful artwork and calm story inspired a peaceful and relaxed mood.   As for replay value, I am uncertain. In certain circumstances, if I felt the need to relax without killing things while listening to 'witty' dialogue this definitely might be a good choice.

Unique point-and-click adventure game, with the puzzles frequently involving the fact that the game's scenery is a bunch of paper objects glued together. Only negative point is one 'find the hidden things' puzzle, which tarnishes an otherwise great experience.
The visuals and music are beautiful. The pace is slow and the puzzles are fairly casual in their difficulty, but I enjoyed the experience of playing this game.
Fun, relaxing, and really beautiful, but it's so short. :'(
The game is beautiful and atmospheric, but very, very short. However, the subtle puzzle challenge, beautiful music and amazing graphics make up for its short length. Very lovely game. I enjoyed it.

This is an indescribably beautiful game. Hands down.   Everything moves at the rate of a pop-up book, which is to say carefully slow. Sometimes annoyingly when if you get stuck stuck on one of the counting puzzles. But, gosh, everything was just beautiful and I spent a good chunk of time just staring at the environment and taking in the scene. I haven't seen a pop-up book since I was in elementary school, and I just felt so mesmerized by everything. My only true regret is that I wish I could have pulled on more things.  The music had a habit of cutting out mid-song, but when it was around it was just so relaxing. My game crash during the ending, so I never really got that happy closure feeling. But the experience was just fun, relaxing, and I enjoyed every minute of it.
This is a test.  maddox

A pretty game with a good soundtrack, but it feels very incomplete. Levels are short, there are just a few very straightforward puzzles, and 90% of gameplay is walking. Incredibly slowly. Feels very tedious, to the point that I needed a logic puzzle running in the background to occupy my time while waiting for the character to reach his destination. I would like to see more levels, more interesting puzzles, and a run toggle.

The ponderous load times and the slow walk speed of the protagonist will get on your nerves, but they are pretty much the only thing padding out the measly 1.5 hour play time investment. For the retail price of 10.00, this is pretty criminal; I'm not even sure I would feel 1.00 would be a fair price. The art is indeed very nice, and the pop-up mechanic is nostalgic and attactive; even the music is pretty fair. But over all: meh.

Beautiful little puzzle game with a Japanese pop-up book aesthetic. Average completion time seems to be around 1-1.5 hours so it's the sort of game you boot up and finish in one sitting. Mechanically the game isn't particularly deep, combining rudimentary logic puzzles with counting and memorisation so the brevity made sure the game never outstayed its welcome. The story appears at first to be deliberately vague but the final credits shed a little bit of light on the overall purpose and meaning of the game so it's worth finishing to experience that. I found the art style and scene transitions charming and the music delightfully tranquil, it's a soothing, reflective experience and by calling it an 'experience' you'll almost certainly know if this sort of game is for you.
A really beautiful game.

+ Pretty Design + Unique game  - Someones can't read chinese - Wapanese - TOO SHORT - NO LOGIC - TOO EXPENSIVE FOR THIS - MISS MATCHED SONGS - MUSICS DON'T HAVE FADE-IN and OUT - NO ESC? SERIOUSLY?!    3/10
It was ok. A bit slow paced, but the puzzles were clever and the animation was gorgeous!  A nice play for point and click adventure fans.

I'm not sure I would call Tengami a game. It's certainly an experience. Extremely slow-paced, with gorgeous visuals and meditative music, it's highly relaxing. The puzzles are not particularly challenging, but not tedious either. Sadly, it's incredibly short, which is unfortunate. The game mechanics are genious and could have been used to creat even more than this. The art is cerainly unique and in my opinion beautiful.  It is worth experiencing, but do not expect a puzzle game is the usual sense. As part of a bundle this 1.5 hour experience was wonderful. At full price, however, I would personally not recommend it.
Simply brilliant and beautiful, but a bit too short. You should be able to finsish it within 2 hours.
+Beautiful, atmospheric, amazing soundtrack, decent puzzles -Short, a little too abstract in story for my taste

I recommend this as a peace of art. If you want to experience a really unique style then check it out!  However I do not recommend it as a game. It has many issues which are really annoying: - the main character is as fast as a snail - the puzzles have a design like: go to the end to figure out what to do. Then go back to the start and collect all the stuff / information you need to solve the puzzle and go back to the end again. Repeat this for everything you missed at the first place... - the music sometimes stops randomly - it is often not really clear what to do. The Hint feature helps here a bit. However for the last puzzle there is no hint feature and it is absolutely not obvious what to do (My hint for you: Find a symmetric pattern). - The game is really short. I finished it within 74 minutes. If the Main Character could run, I guess I would have been solving it in 45 minutes. If he could teleport, It would last about 20 minutes. (You see: the thing you do most of the time in this game is watching the character walking... He is even slower when taking stairs. I was shouting at him to go faster and tried to push some keys to increase the game speed... no chance.)   So the game is really bad but the style is awsome. I recommend it only for people who appreciate art.
Good game, rich story, kind of boring... BUT THE GUY WALKS SO SLOW it takes forever to do anything... so NOT recommended

Tengami is a short, but beautiful and fun puzzle experience. Its all about the atmosphere, this game. Can be completed in 2 hours if you overthink stuff, like me. In any case if you ever have some free time on your hands or its raining, try it out.

Tengami is not long and complex, far from it. In fact, I'd say it might actually be a bit too short. However, it is a very interesting and decent game. The controls are simple, the graphics are pretty good and the soundtrack is nice on your ears. If you're on the look for something different, give this game a try.
Waited so long for the PC release, now finally its here! Its a piece of Art, like a walking meditation. Five stars! (:
Beautiful game, the soundtrack complements the scenery nicely, I found myself completely immersed in the game after completing the first flower. Fantastic game.

Very pleasant and relaxing game. The game is somewhat simplistic as some reviewers have noted, but the beauty of the artwork and animation is the real draw. It is a bit pricy for the 1.5-2 hours of gameplay. Wait until it's on sale.
Fun game. Not overly hard. Visually beautiful. An enjoyable few hours of game play. I would recommend it.

A fun little game with a unique concept of paper-folding art and game mechanics stemming from pop-up books. Puzzles range in difficulty but nothing is unfair. The music is calm and relaxing. Outside of the pop-up book mechanics, the game offers pretty standard faire in terms of game play (it's all point-and-click). It currently stands at $10 USD, and I feel the content is a bit shallow to justify that price. Though it's a darn good pick-up if you can get it for around half that. Aside from that, a solid game. 7/10.

Beutiful artstyle, and amazing music. Its real suttle, buit if u actually listen too it, it can eassely swallow u up.  Kind of a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ending, but all in all a good purchase and I'm glad i played it!!

It's slow moving, and the story is told through Haikus. Recommend smoking a bowl and enjoying the beautiful artwork presented here, will take about an hour and a half, to two hours. Pick up on a sale for sure.

A bit pricy for what it is (very short, not much to do except enjoying the nice animations), but relaxing and original.  I think it could have been much more than what it is though, and lacks a bit of polish. Overall, you may enjoy it if you care more about the aesthetic than the gameplay

Okay, here's the thing about this game, similar to what many others are saying: absolutely gorgeous game, just too short for the price.  I have to give this a thumbs up because I thoroughly enjoyed my experience with this game. The game is incredibly relaxing and scenic, the puzzles require some thought but are not frustrating, the pop-up book style is well done and very unique. I actually enjoyed the characters slow pace and I didn't mind that there wasn't a real plot, this is exactly the kind of game I have been looking to play as a way to relax at the end of stressful day.  All those compliments said, I finished the game in less than 2 hours. I aknowledge that a lot of work and artistry went into creating each page of this game, but 2 hours of game play does not justify the price point in my opinion. I recommend Monument Valley, similar vibe, more gameplay.   I don't regret my purchase, this was a great game, just be aware if you decide to give it a go.

A very nice, different, and beautiful experience. Many reviews comments the the figure is moving slow. He IS ACTUALLY RUNNING but slows down a little when he moves up stairs. It would look unnatural and not in harmony wiht the set, it he moves faster. Do not focus on the price, but on this special experience. As in your life, don't rush throught it, you'll dead regread it when it's over.

Although the game is rather short (just over an hour for me, and honestly it feels like it needed one more chapter), the puzzles are sufficiently complicated considering the tone of the game, not too easy, not too frustrating.  Regardless, the visuals and music in this game are virtually FLAWLESS. This game's asthetic puts even your fondest memories of Okami to shame. I tried looking for flaws in even the rendering of the visuals and found none, and the music is a relaxing, interesting mix of japanese classical and electronic ambient.
Very cool relaxing game, unique visual style of pop-up book and some clever mechanic and puzzles using this style. Very nice little game :)

Was gifted this from a friend for Christmas. Really lovely little point-and-click puzzle game with beautiful scenery and calming music. Wouldn't say any of the puzzles were particularly difficult but the mechanics of pulling flaps and folding pages made them a little more interesting than your standard basic puzzles. Don't think it's worth the original price but definitely worth picking up during the sales if you want to zone out with something peaceful for an hour during the holidays.

Wait, what?  This is a very short and relaxing game. A few key puzzle that require solving. I seem to enjoy these short stories, however the story* itself wasn't anything too special.  The way the story is told together with the gameplay mechanics is quite unique and new to me (The whole Paper-Folding mechanics). I enjoyed it and it's definitely something worth experiencing (if it's 75%+ off)  Cons: Lacking basic audio adjusment setting. Very short, so not worth the price.

This isn't so much a thumbs down as a 'meh', but if you like what you see in the trailer, and the music, and just the relaxed 'feel' of the environment you might like this game. Visually it looks great and the folding nature of the world is unique. The puzzles were sortof OK, but I gotta admit I lost interest before reaching the end. I recently just finished it because it had been sitting unfinished for many months and ... you know how it is, sometimes you just want to finish something.   Would I recommend it, though? No. Only if this strongly appeals to you.
